Language Lab Gets
$25,000 Renovation
BY DAVID NEWMAN
Renovation of the Language
Lab, including the installation of
$25,000 in new equipment and a
coat of paint, is now complete.
The lab, located in the
basement of Gilman Hall, will
begin serving students taking
courses in the Romance Languages and German Departments
on Monday.
"We had reached the point
where the old equipment became a student detriment," said
Donald Clark, Language Lab
director, referring to the decrepit reel-to-reel machines formerly in use. "We've replaced the
old decks with thirty-two new
cassette decks."
The new recorders, Telex
model 200, feature such improvements as an integrated
microphone, a pause control,
and Braille symbols on the
operating buttons. "We chose
Telex because they're all modular - we also bought a new
duplicator (for recording a master onto a cassette) that fits in
the old cabinet. Right now, we
can record three cassettes from
one master, and we will expand
that later by purchasing another
cassette module," Clark stated.
In addition to equipment
purchases, Clark hopes to upgrade the lab by introducing
material beyond the conventional exercise tapes. One current
project is a lecture series, on a

broad range of topics,"provided
we can measure the student's
comprehension." The lecture
series could be expanded to
include plays and poetry, or
other materials where the student can "abstractly hear the
foreign language."
Plans to replace the 13 year
old equipment began in summer
1979 with the formation of a
Language Lab Committee. Al-

though the lab is ostensibly part
of the Romance Languages Department, a representative of the
German Department also sat on
the committee, which recommended the new equipment
purchase. "Funding then became the problem," Clark
found, but the University, on
Dean Hooker's approval, did put
up the $25,000 necessary for the
overhaul.

Language Lab plans to expand tape selection to include literature.
